name: Pneumococcal vaccine
description: NHS information about the pneumococcal vaccine, including what the vaccine helps protect against, who should have it, how to get it and side effects.

hasPart.description: The pneumococcal vaccine protects against serious illnesses like pneumonia and sepsis. It's recommended for people at higher risk of these illnesses.

hasPart.headline: Pneumococcal vaccine
hasPart.text: Side effects
The pneumococcal vaccine helps protect against some types of infections that can cause serious illnesses like meningitis, sepsis and pneumonia.
The pneumococcal vaccine is for babies, adults aged 65 and over, and people at higher risk of getting seriously ill from pneumococcal infections.
Most people who need it can have the pneumococcal vaccine. You cannot have it if you've had a serious allergic reaction to it or an ingredient in it.
Your GP surgery should contact you to arrange you or your child's pneumococcal vaccinations. Welders and metal workers should speak to their employer.
Side effects of the pneumococcal vaccine include swelling or pain where the injection was given, a high temperature, tiredness and loss of appetite.

hasPart.description: The pneumococcal vaccine helps protect against some types of infections that can cause serious illnesses like meningitis, sepsis and pneumonia.

hasPart.text:
The pneumococcal vaccine helps protect against some types of bacterial infections that can cause serious illnesses like:

  • meningitis (an infection in the brain and spinal cord)
  • sepsis (a life-threatening reaction to an infection)
  • pneumonia (an infection in the lungs)

It can also help protect against other illnesses such as sinusitis and ear infections.

hasPart.headline: What the pneumococcal vaccine is for

hasPart.description: The pneumococcal vaccine is for babies, adults aged 65 and over, and people at higher risk of getting seriously ill from pneumococcal infections.

hasPart.text: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for babies, older people, and people at higher risk of getting seriously ill from pneumococcal infections.
Contact your GP surgery if you or your child have missed a pneumococcal vaccination.

hasPart.headline: Who's at higher risk of getting seriously ill
hasPart.text:
You're at higher risk of getting seriously ill from pneumococcal infections if you have:

  • sickle cell disease, coeliac disease, problems with your spleen or you've had your spleen removed
  • a long-term condition that affects your breathing such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or cystic fibrosis
  • a long-term condition that affects your heart such as coronary heart disease or heart failure
  • chronic kidney disease
  • a long-term condition that affects your liver such as cirrhosis
  • diabetes
  • a weakened immune system due to a condition such as HIV, or a treatment such as steroid medicine or chemotherapy
  • a condition where fluid that protects the brain and spinal cord leaks out (cerebrospinal fluid leaks)
  • cochlear implants

Some welders and metal workers who are exposed to metal fumes at work should also have the vaccine. Check with your employer if you think you may need it.

hasPart.headline: Who should have the pneumococcal vaccine

hasPart.description: Most people who need it can have the pneumococcal vaccine. You cannot have it if you've had a serious allergic reaction to it or an ingredient in it.

hasPart.text:
Most people can have the pneumococcal vaccine if they need it, including if you're pregnant or breastfeeding.

You only cannot have the vaccine if you've had a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or an ingredient in the vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Information
hasPart.text:
Getting vaccinated if you're unwell

If you or your child have a high temperature or feel too unwell to do your normal activities, wait until you're feeling better before having the vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Who cannot have the pneumococcal vaccine

hasPart.description: You can check the ingredients in the pneumococcal vaccine by asking to see the patient leaflet or searching for it online.

hasPart.text:
There are 2 types of pneumococcal vaccine given in the UK. You can check the ingredients in the patient leaflets:

  • Pneumovax pneumococcal vaccine patient leaflet (Electronic Medicines Compendium website) – usually given to adults and children over 2
  • Prevenar pneumococcal vaccine patient leaflet (Electronic Medicines Compendium website; PDF only, 121kb) – usually given to babies under 2

hasPart.headline: Pneumococcal vaccine ingredients

hasPart.description: Your GP surgery should contact you to arrange you or your child's pneumococcal vaccinations. Welders and metal workers should speak to their employer.

hasPart.text:
Your GP surgery will usually contact you if you or your child are eligible for the pneumococcal vaccine. This will usually be by letter, text, phone call or email.

If you are a welder or metal worker, speak to your employer about getting the vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Speak to your GP surgery if:
hasPart.text:
• you have not been contacted to get the pneumococcal vaccine, but you think you or your child are eligible
  • you or your child have missed your pneumococcal vaccinations, or you're not sure if you've been vaccinated
  • you or your child are unwell – you may need to wait until you're feeling better before having the vaccine
  • you need to change a vaccination appointment

Your GP surgery can book or rearrange an appointment.

hasPart.headline: Information
hasPart.text:
Having the pneumococcal vaccine at the same time as other vaccines

You can get the pneumococcal vaccine at the same time as other vaccines, such as the flu vaccine.

hasPart.headline: How to get the pneumococcal vaccine

hasPart.description: Side effects of the pneumococcal vaccine include swelling or pain where the injection was given, a high temperature, tiredness and loss of appetite.

hasPart.text:
Like all medicines, the pneumococcal vaccine can cause side effects, but not everyone gets them.

Common side effects

The most common side effects of the pneumococcal vaccine include:

  • swelling or pain where the injection was given
  • a high temperature
  • feeling tired
  • loss of appetite

Babies and children may also feel a bit unwell and irritable.

You can give them child's paracetamol or child's ibuprofen to ease any symptoms.

Check the packaging or leaflet to make sure the medicine is suitable for your child, or speak to a pharmacist or doctor if you're not sure.

hasPart.headline: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or call 111 if your baby:
hasPart.text:
• is under 3 months old and has a temperature of 38C or higher, or you think they have a high temperature
  • is 3 to 6 months old and has a temperature of 39C or higher, or you think they have a high temperature
  • has a seizure (fit)
  • is unwell and you're worried about them

hasPart.headline: Allergic reactions
hasPart.text:
More serious side effects such as a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) are very rare and usually happen within minutes.

The person who vaccinates you will be trained to deal with allergic reactions and treat them immediately.

hasPart.headline: Side effects of the pneumococcal vaccine

hasPart.description: The pneumococcal vaccine gives some protection by about 3 weeks from when you've had it. Most adults only need 1 dose for long-term protection.

hasPart.text:
Vaccination gives the best protection against pneumococcal infections.

It helps protect against the most common and serious types of these infections, but there's still a chance you might get a pneumococcal infection.

You usually have some protection by about 3 weeks from when you had the vaccine.

Most adults only need 1 dose of the vaccine for long-term protection. Most babies need 2 doses to protect them.

mainEntityOfPage.text:
Vaccination gives the best protection against pneumococcal infections.

It helps protect against the most common and serious types of these infections, but there's still a chance you might get a pneumococcal infection.

You usually have some protection by about 3 weeks from when you had the vaccine.

Most adults only need 1 dose of the vaccine for long-term protection. Most babies need 2 doses to protect them.
